title: Ex-gang leader who was living on the streets at 13 wins Pride of Britain award
text:

Hezron Brown can point to each of the numerous scars across his face and body and tell a close-shave story of life or death.

The 29-year-old fell into an inner-city Birmingham gang as a teenager and knows how lucky he is to still be alive today.

There was the time he was surrounded by 30 rival gang members armed with knives at a bus stop. It was only running full pelt that saved him then.

The time another rival smashed a mirror over his head. The time guys from his own gang turned on him with a metal bar during a dispute.

And the time during a fight he was passed a knife to protect himself, only to then be battered into the side of a car, crushing his hand and pushing the weapon clean through it.

(Image: Hezron Brown/BPM Media)

These are the stories he now tells young teens who find themselves, like he was, drawn to gang culture, often due to a sense of not belonging, little hope for their futures, or because their own families have broken down.

And it is Hezron’s achievement in turning his own life around, and his dedication to helping others do the same, which has seen him crowned Prince’s Trust Young Achiever at the Mirror’s Pride of Britain Awards, in partnership with TSB.

“I show the young people the scars on my face, my hands, and I tell them what happened with each one,” he explains.

“I see how it opens up their eyes. They have been in those situations, they know it could have gone wrong.

"I say 'Any of those times I could have lost my life.' I make them concentrate on their lives. I tell them the gang does not love them and there is another life.”

(Image: Daily Mirror/Andy Stenning)

He adds: “I never thought someone like myself would be put forward for something like this. At one point, I didn’t even know if I would be alive today.

“It has made me realise anything is possible, but you have to believe in yourself, and you can achieve. That’s what I try and do for the young people. I want to be the person I didn’t have when I was younger, who they can ask for advice. I needed that person, but I felt alone.”

Today, Hezron runs his own business, More Talk More Action, which aims to reach more young people in this position. He is also a Prince’s Trust Young Ambassador after being signposted as a young man to a theatre scheme run by The Prince’s Trust, which enabled him to first find employment.

It is a life far from his experiences as a child and teenager.

Aged five, a terrible accident saw Hezron fall into a bath of boiling water at home and suffer debilitating burns across his body.

But it was the bullying he suffered when he came out of hospitaland started school which was to have the most damaging effect.

(Image: Daily Mirror/Andy Stenning)

Hezron’s method for coping with the bullies became to fight back, and soon he developed anger issues which spiralled and affected both his school and home life.

He was excluded from both primary and secondary schools, and admits his own mum became frightened by his outbursts and their relationship eventually broke down.

“It was a cycle, I became so angry I wouldn’t know what I was doing. I was violent towards my mum, my whole family. She was scared of me,” he admits.

From a young age he sofa-surfed with friends and family, and even found himself sleeping rough as young as 12.

By 15 he was housed in emergency accommodation, then a B&B and finally given a council flat, but he felt completely alone, frightened, and struggled to cope with the pressures of adult life.

By 17, kicked out of college after a row with a tutor, he was drawn into the gang.

“It offered me a family, to me it was a bunch of brothers who would support each other, it made me feel safer” he explains.

(Image: Daily Record)

“A lot of them were in similar positions to myself. It was just good to be part of something – I wasn’t doing anything else.”

Hezron began selling drugs, and although he didn’t carry a knife for fear of being stopped and searched by the police, he opted instead for a sharp pair of scissors as a “deterrent” he explains.

“A lot of young people I speak today carry a knife,” he says. “But they do it out of fear. They don’t want to be a victim, they tell me they wouldn’t leave their house without a knife.”

Hezron remained with the gang for around two years. In the end, it took just one supportive comment from one empathetic person to help him decide to leave. It was what he had been waiting for.

Finding himself convicted for robbery aged 19, he went to his pre-sentencing report appointment, and the woman writing it greeted him sadly.

(Image: Daily Record)

He recalls: “She said ‘Not another black man’. She asked me what had happened and she told me ‘You don’t deserve to go to prison. She seem like a nice guy, hanging around with the wrong crowd.” She told me things would only get worse if I went to prison.

“She wrote my report, and I didn’t go to prison. It made me realise that everything I was doing was pointless.”

Hezron says he immediately stopped hanging out with the guys in the gang.

Determined to change completely he went shopping and ditched his black hoodie and balaclava for a white top and new jeans.

(Image: Philip Coburn)

Of course, finding a new way of life wasn’t as easy as that, but with a new determination he sought out education, re-took some exams and learnt new skills.

Signposted to The Prince’s Trust Get Started with Theatre, a week-long programme, he then secured a job at the Birmingham Rep Theatre.

“I found self-respect and self-belief,” he says.

“I realised I was not a bad person, I was getting caught up in bad things.”
description: Hezron Brown, from Birmingham, will be given his Pride of Britain award tonight after turning his life around
